title: Oskar David Ginsberger
text:
Oskar David Ginsberger (2 February 18961 February 1979) was a <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>n physician (dermatovenerologist) and <a href="Yugoslav%20Partisans">Partisan</a> member during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
Ginsberger was born in <a href="Gradi%C5%A1te%2C%20Croatia">Gradište</a>, in the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Croatia-Slavonia">Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia</a> on 2 February 1896 to a <a href="Jews%20in%20Croatia">Jewish family</a>. He finished grammar school in Gradište, and attended <a href="Gymnasium%20%28school%29">gymnasium</a> in <a href="Vinkovci">Vinkovci</a> and <a href="Zagreb">Zagreb</a>. In 1914 Ginsberger graduated from the Faculty of Medicine at the <a href="University%20of%20Graz">University of Graz</a>. He completed dermatovenereology <a href="academic%20specialization">academic specialization</a> in Vienna, 1922. Upon return to Osijek, he worked as a private physician. During World War II, in 1942, he joined the Partisans as a member of the VII. Banijska brigada (<a href="Banovina%20%28region%29">Banovina</a> brigade). After the war he worked at the <a href="Sisak">Sisak</a> <a href="community%20health%20center">community health center</a>. He worked on sexually transmitted diseases and their control. Ginsberger wrote articles which were published in local and western professional medical journals from 1925 to 1965. He translated the book of <a href="J%C3%BCrgen%20Thorwald">Jürgen Thorwald</a> "Das Jahrhundert der Chirurgen" and Herbert Franks "Aufstand der Herzen". Ginsberger retired in 1953, but worked privately until 1965. He died in <a href="St.%20Gallen">St. Gallen</a>, <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a> on 1 February 1979.
